abstract: What in the World column; New Zealand has granted personhood to former national park Te Urewera, ending dispute between government and Maori groups; Whanganui River is set to receive similar legal designation.

headline.print_headline: In New Zealand, Rivers and Parks Are People, Too (Legally, at Least)
headline.main: In New Zealand, Lands and Rivers Can Be People (Legally Speaking)

snippet: In a deal with Maori groups, Parliament has agreed on a way to protect natural features without them being owned by anyone, including the state....
lead_paragraph: In a deal with Maori groups, Parliament has agreed on a way to protect natural features without them being owned by anyone, including the state.
